conversation.text: Hi, how can I help you with the recipe?
Need assistance to saute baby carrots
Start by washing the carrots before putting them in the pot
evidence: Wash your carrots before putting them in the pot
Thoroughly rinse your carrots in the sink before cooking with them
Make sure they’re clean of anything that was on them
Parboil 1 pound (0.45 kg) of carrots for 5 minutes

conversation.text: Put enough water to cover your carrots in a pot and get just the water to a rolling boil. Toss the carrots in at that point and cook the carrots till they're still crisper than al dente. Then strain all the water and leave the carrots in the pot until ready for sauteeing.
evidence: water has reached a rolling boil
toss in the carrots, and boil them as you normally would
make sure their texture remains even crisper than an al dente bite
When they’re done, strain the carrots from the water, but leave them in the pot
Make sure the carrots are completely submerged in the water when you’re boiling

conversation.text: What do I do when they're ready for sauteeing?
Move onto sauteeing with a small frying pan

In a small frying pan, use 2 tablespoons of butter and 1 tablespoon of oil to cook with. Chop up some green onions or shallots to saute with the carrots. You can also add other vegetables that don't need to be parboiled, such as broccoli, cauliflower, green beans, or bell pepper, none of which need to be parboiled. Cook your veggies for 2 minutes, tossing and turning often before adding the carrots. Saute them for another two minutes before adding 30 ml brown sugar to the pan. Continue tossing and turning the veggies to coat with the brown sugar. Turn the heat off at a minute and be careful not to burn the brown sugar in the pan.
evidence: Use 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of butter, and 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of the oil to cook with
Chop up green onions or shallots to sauté with the carrots
Some other vegetables you could add are chopped broccoli or cauliflower, green beans, or bell pepper
They do not have to be parboiled beforehand
Turn the vegetables around often
Cook them this way for a full 2 minutes before adding the carrots
Add ⁄8 cup (30 mL) of brown sugar to the pan and cook for 1 more minute
Add the carrots to the pan and continue to sauté for 2 more minutes

conversation.text: Okay, and then they can be served?

Yes, place the veggies on your serving plate and while still hot you can add a bit of parsley on top to mix in with the vegetables. Leftovers can be stored in the fridge in a plastic container with a lid.
evidence: place the vegetables on your serving plate
while everything’s still hot, add the parsley on top to mix in its flavor
Store leftovers in the fridge in a plastic container with a lid

conversation.text: Congratulations! You have successfully completed this cooking task.

procedure.summary: Wash your carrots before putting them in the pot.
procedure.description: Thoroughly rinse your carrots in the sink before cooking with them. Make sure they’re clean of anything that was on them, such as dirt or packaging materials.

procedure.summary: Parboil 1 pound (0.45 kg) of carrots for 5 minutes.
procedure.description: Parboiling is partially cooking a food by boiling it first to prepare it to be cooked another way. In this case, you’ll be parboiling the carrots to make them firmer, and thus easier to sear in the pan when you go to sauté them. After the water has reached a rolling boil, toss in the carrots, and boil them as you normally would. As they cook, make sure their texture remains even crisper than an al dente bite. When they’re done, strain the carrots from the water, but leave them in the pot until they’re ready to be added to the pan for sautéing. Make sure the carrots are completely submerged in the water when you’re boiling them. Don’t start the timer until bubbles are rolling at the surface of the water. 1 pound (0.45 kg) of carrots will serve 2-3 people.

procedure.summary: Chop up green onions or shallots to sauté with the carrots.
procedure.description: While you’re letting the carrots parboil, on a cutting board, cut up either 1 bunch (6-8 stems) of long green onions, or 2 shallots to cook with the carrots. Cut them into small enough pieces so they will quickly sauté and caramelize in the pan. Some other vegetables you could add are chopped broccoli or cauliflower, green beans, or bell pepper. They do not have to be parboiled beforehand. Use enough in proportion to the onions or shallots.

procedure.summary: Sauté the onions or shallots in a pan with oil and butter for 2 minutes.
procedure.description: In a small frying pan start cooking the onions you chopped up. Turn the vegetables around often with a spoon or spatula, or shift them around with the entire pan if you’re practiced. Cook them this way for a full 2 minutes before adding the carrots. Use 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of butter, and 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of the oil to cook with.

procedure.summary: Add the carrots to the pan and continue to sauté for 2 more minutes.
procedure.description: Keep turning the vegetables with the spoon or spatula so everything cooks evenly. Try to coat all the vegetables in the oil and butter. Stir for a bit before letting the vegetables sear in place a little. Keep repeating for 2 minutes.

procedure.summary: Add ⁄8 cup (30 mL) of brown sugar to the pan and cook for 1 more minute.
procedure.description: After cooking the carrots for 2 minutes, go ahead and add the brown sugar. Continue to keep moving the vegetables around to make sure it gets on them all to have them be caramelized. Be careful to not cook longer than a minute, or you could risk burning the brown sugar, ruining the carrots. Turn the heat on your stove off after the 1 minute passes, and move the pan to a different part of the stove, or off it, to keep the vegetables from continuing to cook in the still hot pan.

procedure.summary: Sprinkle ⁄4 cup (59 mL) of chopped parsley over the sautéed vegetables.
procedure.description: Chop up the parsley into small pieces. Once they’re fully cooked, place the vegetables on your serving plate, and while everything’s still hot, add the parsley on top to mix in its flavor. Distribute the parsley evenly onto the vegetables, so no part has too much or too little. Store leftovers in the fridge in a plastic container with a lid.
